3. What you think you measure, and what you actually measure, surprisingly often doesn’t coincide

2012-09-25 15:42:00 -0600

It is worthwhile spending some time up front conceptualizing your KPIs.

What does success look like?

Look at your goals; this will guide you in selecting your KPIs. A clear understanding of your goals is vital to getting the data you need—and providing the insights and analysis your team relies on.

Your analysis will be garbage if your metrics don’t align with your goals, plain and simple. When defining KPIs against goals, remember that a KPI should be something that:

  • Measures performance
  • Measures success against stated business goals
  • Should  contain the specific measurement scale

After jotting down a set of metrics, spend some time paring it back. Lots of variables is all nice and good, but analysis can get cumbersome with too many metrics. Remember, key signifies importance in relation to other indicators, so whittle your metrics down to the essentials. 

KPIs can be measured on any time interval (by minute, hourly, daily, monthly, etc.) depending upon the data collection for the metric and the value it provides at specific intervals. However, as a rule of thumb, the higher resolution, or more granular, data you can capture the better; it minimizes data loss down the line. You can always aggregate later, if your needs call for it. Go for as high a granularity as you can afford.

Search marketing outlook for the remainder of 2012

2012-09-17 19:32:00 -0600

Adobe just released their global digital advertising update for Q2 2012, and things are looking good in search marketing!

Insights gleaned from analyzing data from over 5,000 companies worldwide that use the Adobe Digital Marketing Suite show paid search continued the growth trend from Q1 across industries, and both spend and ROI improved. This was driven by lower CPC. 

Especially interesting is that tablet and mobile show very competitive ROI, and should be a major focus going forward. The figures below show this really well.

Facebook is still an uncertain channel, but brands are getting a better hang on using social to drive fan growth and engagement. Adobe suggests these positive changes for Facebook-driven marketing were driven by changes made to the Facebook platform in the last two quarters (e.g. Timeline) and new and better engagement and acquisition metrics.

Check out the full report for all the details and to learn where Adobe expects some key trends in social marketing to head into the second half of 2012.

2. Remember K.I.S.S.

2012-09-16 18:47:00 -0600

When attacking a data-driven business question, keep it simple, stupid!

At least do this until you have a good understanding of the problem, and your most important stakeholders are on board and do too.

Doing this accomplishes a few critical things:

One, you save yourself a lot of unnecessary work if your analysis isn’t what your stakeholders want.

Two, keeping your analysis straightforward builds trust in your recommendations and findings. People won’t get the impression you’re trying to pull wool over their eyes.

And three, there’s usually just not a really good reason for  sophisticated statistics in most real-world analytics. At least not where the field stands today. Besides, why start an (unnecessary) arms race when you don’t have to? 

Clarity trumps sophistication, every time.
